Enter the Email address associated with your account.
We will email you a link to reset your password
What aspect/s of hiking do you like to experience most?
TrailBlaze utilizes your location to provide personalized suggestions of nearby trails, please enter your location.
How far would you like to receive suggested trails?
How would you like to interact with the community>
I would like my account to be found by others.
I would like my hiking experience shared with others and/or on leaderboards.
I would like to volunteer for creating and maintaining trails for my community.
I would like to be notified if someone is in danger or any potential danger is on a trail.
Please select your preferences for each of the categories listed below.
Your privacy is important to us. It is TrailBlaze policy to respect your privacy regarding any information we may collect from you across our website, and other sites we own and operate.

We only ask for personal information when we truly need it to provide a service to you. We collect it by fair and lawful means, with your knowledge and consent. We also let you know why we’re collecting it and how it will be used.
We only retain collected information for as long as necessary to provide you with your requested service.">
By signing in you are agreeing to our
Stay hydrated: Dehydration can be a serious health problem, so bring more water than you think youll need. Use a durable water bottle to ensure you have access to clean water.
Wear proper footwear: Wear quality closed-toe shoes with good cushioning and grip to avoid sore feet and ankle injuries.
Dress in layers: Wear clothes that work for the weather and avoid cotton.
Carry essentials: Bring a flashlight, matches, emergency shelter, and extra food and water.
Know your limits: Be aware of your physical abilities and listen to your body. Recognize signs of fatigue or distress, such as shortness of breath or dizziness.
Stay on marked trails: Making shortcuts can lead to erosion and increase your chances of getting lost.
Dont climb on waterfalls: Falls from waterfalls and wet rocks can cause serious injuries and deaths.
Use a whistle: A whistle can be heard from far away and takes less energy than yelling.
Dont rely on cell phones: Dont count on cell phones to work in the wilderness.
Never feed or touch wildlife: Do not approach or attempt to move sick or injured wildlife. Please report any encounters with aggressive, sick or injured animals to a park staff.

Wildlife lives in all state parks, even near urban areas: Although rare, black bears, mountain lions and rattlesnakes may be seen. If you encounter wildlife on the trail, keep your distance, back away slowly and do not run. Report your sightings to park staff.

Ticks: Tick populations can increase depending on the season. Take the following precautions to avoid them: Walk in the middle of trails. Use insect repellent. Tuck your pants into your socks. After taking off gear, check for hitchhiking ticks. Always do a “tick check” with the help of a friend.

Poison oak: It is a common plant throughout much of California. Learn to identify its shiny, three-leaf pattern, and avoid touching it. If you touch poison oak, wash immediately with water and mild soap. Pat dry with a clean towel.
But mostly have fun! Enjoy nature! Love yourself. And remember leave only footprints, and take only memories!

Snakes: Always know where you are stepping. For example, if you must traverse a log that has fallen across the trail, rather than just stepping over the log, first step up onto the log then step down once you know the coast is clear. Be cautious when climbing rocks or picking up firewood. If you see a snake, maintain a distance of at least 6 feet. Most bites occur when people get too close or try to touch them.
Mountain Climber: Visit a park that has a hiking activity.
Long-Distance Trekker: Hike a certain amount of time.
Habitual Hiker: Hike 2 trails a week.
Weekend Warrior: Complete a trail during the weekend.
Daily Adventurer: Hike at least once a day for a week.
Explorer: Complete a trail in the evening.
Trail Master: Complete trails in all four seasons.
Social Butterfly: Add at least 2 TrailBlazers.
Team Player: Complete a trail with a party of friends.
Safety Expert: Look at the safety tips.
Community Builder: Add a favorite friend.
Wildlife Watcher: Complete a trail with a Wildlife activity.
Photographer: Upload a picture to your TrailBlaze.
Goal Setter: Add your badges to your sash.
Badge Collector: Earn badges for completing specific challenges or achievements.
Leaderboard Climber: Get at least 2 badges.
If you are experiencing any issues, please let us know. We will try to solve them as soon as possible.
You can also contact us at

TrailBlaze aims to be the go-to application for all hikers, climbers, and outdoorsy types by offering a fantastic way to view trail options whether traveling or at home. With customization options, the latest updates on trails, and an expansive community, it is sure to be a standout in the space.

The information provided when using the Services is not intended for distribution to or use by any person or entity in any jurisdiction or country where such distribution or use would be contrary to law or regulation which would subject us to any registration requirement within such jurisdiction or country. Accordingly, those persons who choose to access the Services from other locations do so on their own initiative and are solely responsible for compliance with local laws, if and to the extent local laws are applicable.

Adds current park to user\'s bucket list
This badge is awarded for exceptional response time to your Blazers messages. You have shown time and time again that you are there for your Blazer when they need you most!! Congratulations!!
Would you like to designate Watcher(s) for your account?
Watchers are trusted contacts that can monitor your journey in real-time to stay safe and connected.
